abstract.text: The appropriate focus in dealing with the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States has been 2 addressing access and delivery of care to the population impacted by the outbreak. All sectors of 3 the U.S economy have been significantly impacted including physicians. Physician groups of all 4 specialties and sizes have experienced the financial impact of the pandemic. Hospitals have 5 received billions of dollars to support and enable them to handle emergencies and cover the cost 6 of the disruption. However, many Vascular Surgeons are under great financial pressure because 7 of postponement of all non-emergency procedures. The Federal Government has announced a 8 myriad of programs in the form of grants and loans to reimburse physicians for some expenses 9

and loss of revenue. It is more than likely that unless the public health emergency subsides 10 significantly, many practices will suffer dire consequences without additional financial 11 assistance. We attempt to provide a concise listing of such programs and resources available to 12 assist Vascular Surgeons who are small businesses in accessing these opportunities.

The COVID-19 global pandemic has brought a time of grave uncertainty for U.S. healthcare and 15 the greater economy. While the focus of healthcare providers is, appropriately, on the access to 16 and delivery of care to those impacted by the COVID-19 outbreak, there are many independent 17 specialists who will require financial resources to persevere during a time when they are unable 18 to conduct regular business.

A recent survey of 724 physician respondents in the first week of April 2020 reported that 97% 21 of medical practices have been negatively impacted directly or indirectly by COVID-19. 1 A 70% 22 decrease in surgical procedures and a 33% decrease in office visit was reported. Importantly, 23 75% of respondents were in independent practices consisting of fewer than 50 full-time 24 3 equivalent physicians. The 2017 Society for Vascular Surgery workforce survey, consisting of 1 714 respondents, found that 44.6% were in academic practice, 23.6% in self-employed private 2 practice, 19.9% in hospital employed private practice, and 12% in a group private practice. 2 In 3

The Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), to which $349 billion was allocated; 13 (2) The Emergency Economic Injury Disaster Loans (EIDL); 14 (3) The Coronavirus Economic Stabilization Act (CESA); and, 15 (4) The Small Business Debt Relief Program. 6 16 17 HHS has also taken agency action, separate from Congress, to distribute almost $34 billion to 18 providers through the much-expanded Accelerated and Advance Payment Program. 7 Prior to the 19 COVID-19 pandemic, this program had approved only 100 requests for accelerated/advance 20 payment over the past five years. 7 Since approximately April 1st, CMS has approved over 21 17,000 such requests, with payments being issued within seven days. 7 22 23 5 A couple of noteworthy points regarding these programs:

(1) Businesses may obtain loans under both the PPP and the EIDL, so long as they cover 3 different expenses; 6 and, 4 (2) Providers who receive more than $150,000 in total federal government funding related to 5 COVID-19 will be required to submit a report to HHS disclosing the total amount received and 6 an itemized list of how the received funds were spent. 8

Although not immediate, physician practices may also be eligible for various tax credits. For 9 example, the Employee Retention Tax Credit provides an employee retention tax credit of 50% 10 on wages, up to $10,000 per employee. This credit is applicable to wages paid or incurred 11 between March 13 and December 31, 2020, as well as a portion of the cost of employer-provided 12 healthcare benefits. 9 Eligible businesses include those who are not in receipt of a PPP loan and 13 whose: (1) operations have been fully/partly suspended due to a Stay at Home Order; or (2) gross 14 receipts declined by more than 50% compared to same quarter of 2019. 15 16 In addition, there are many laws which impact Vascular Surgeons that have been relaxed, and 17 new rules that have been written, for this national emergency. These include: 18 19 (1) A 20% increase in Medicare payments to hospitals related to treatment of COVID-19 20 inpatients; 3

(2) A suspension of Medicare sequestration (which will effectively increase most Medicare 22 provider reimbursement by 2%) through the end of 2020; including Vascular Surgeons, to provide more than 80 additional services to beneficiaries, 3 regardless of whether the beneficiary is in a rural community, or whether the provider is located 4 out of state. These services are currently allowed to be provided via non-secure apps, such as consequences for small and medium size VS practices will be, insolvency is a possibility pushing 8 surgeons to seek safety and employment with larger groups or health systems. Meanwhile, the 9 short-term financial implications are worrisome. On April 16, 2020 the SBA announced that the 10 $349 billion program to assist small business ran out of funds. 14 Already, 1.1 million applications 11 asking for $257 billion had been approved by the SBA. 15 What is not clear at this time is how 12 much of that amount has been claimed by physicians. 13 14 In the coming weeks, Vascular Surgeons can expect the federal government to distribute the 15 remaining $70 billion in the Relief Fund to providers, although how that amount will be 16 allocated is yet indeterminate. Further, it is possible that Congress will pass a fourth stimulus 17 plan, although movement forward on that bill is being held up by political posturing. 16 results of any such advocacy, however, remains to be seen. SBA is only required provide a certificate of its compliance with the Act to a financial institution in connection with its first request for access to your financial records. SBA's access rights continue for the term of any approved loan guaranty agreement. SBA is also authorized to transfer to another Government authority any financial records concerning an approved loan or loan guarantee, as necessary to process, service or foreclose on a loan guaranty or collect on a defaulted loan guaranty.Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. 552) -Subject to certain exceptions, SBA must supply information reflected in agency files and records to a person requesting it. Information about approved loans that will be automatically released includes, among other things, statistics on our loan programs (individual borrowers are not identified in the statistics) and other information such as the names of the borrowers (and their officers, directors, stockholders or partners), the collateral pledged to secure the loan, the amount of the loan, its purpose in general terms and the maturity. Proprietary data on a borrower would not routinely be made available to third parties. All requests under this Act are to be addressed to the nearest SBA office and be identified as a Freedom of Information request.Occupational Safety and Health Act (15 U.S.C. 651 et seq.) -The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) can require businesses to modify facilities and procedures to protect employees. Businesses that do not comply may be fined, forced to cease operations, or prevented from starting operations. Signing this form is certification that the applicant, to the best of its knowledge, is in compliance with the applicable OSHA requirements, and will remain in compliance during the life of the loan.Civil Rights (13 C.F.R. 112, 113, 117) -All businesses receiving SBA financial assistance must agree not to discriminate in any business practice, including employment practices and services to the public on the basis of categories cited in 13 C.F.R., Parts 112, 113, and 117 of SBA Regulations. All borrowers must display the "Equal Employment Opportunity Poster" prescribed by SBA.Equal Credit Opportunity Act (15 U.S.C. 1691) -Creditors are prohibited from discriminating against credit applicants on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, marital status or age (provided the applicant has the capacity to enter into a binding contract); because all or part of the applicant's income derives from any public assistance program; or because the applicant has in good faith exercised any right under the Consumer Credit Protection Act.
